questions.text: A 30-year-old male has symptoms like cough, bloody sputum, fever, and night sweats suggestive of tuberculosis. At the clinic, CBNAAT results +. The next step of management will be:

options.label: A
options.text: He is referred for a chest X-ray

options.label: B
options.text: He is declared a Sputum smear –ve case; started with DOTS Cat III treatment

options.label: C
options.text: He is declared a TB case; started with treatment

options.label: D
options.text: He will undergo sputum smear examinations after 6 months again

questions.correct_answer: C. He is declared a TB case; started with treatment
questions.explanation:
Solution:

He is declared a TB case; started with treatment As per RNTCP Diagnosis Guidelines:- After Sputum is positive for Acid Fast Bacilli, the Patient is marked TB +ve, and DOTS category I treatment is started. X-ray is suggested when a sputum smear is -ve, so Chest X-ray is done to diagnose As the Patient is found Positive urgent treatment is started.

questions.text: Guru, 28 years male factory worker, was diagnosed with tuberculosis and has been on ATT for 2 months. One day he presented with a vision problem. He complained that the objects are blurred, and he cannot differentiate between red and green traffic lights. You refer him for further evaluation to ophthalmology OPD. Optic neuritis is diagnosed in this patient. What may be the reason for this?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ethambutol Ethambutol is correct. The patient has been on ATT for 2 months, and has now developed optic neuritis. Vision blurring and difficulty differentiating red and green lights are the symptoms of optic neuritis. Ethambutol is the cause of this.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Rifampicin will not cause vision problems. It mainly causes flu-like symptoms, orange-red discoloration of body fluids, Hepatitis, gastritis, purpura, thrombocytopenia, and nephrotoxicity. Option: B. Isoniazid will not cause vision problems. It is hepatotoxic and may cause peripheral neuropathy which can be prevented by supplementation of vitamin B6 (Pyridoxine). Option: D. Pyrazinamide will not cause vision problems. It is hepatotoxic and may also cause hyperuricemia

questions.text: Ramu, a 35 years old male, came with a fever, productive cough, and chest pain. On examination, all vitals are normal. On chest auscultation, B/L basal coarse crepitations are heard. Spirometry is normal. Sputum smear examination done for AFB turns out positive. Chest X-ray is normal. What is the next step?

options.label: D
options.text: Mark as negative and send home.

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Start ATT Presumptive TB patients should be tested for sputum smear AFB test and chest X-ray. If the sputum smear is positive and the chest X-ray is normal, the patient should be named as microbiologically confirmed TB, and ATT should be initiated.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. There is no need to repeat the sputum smear AFB test if one time it comes out positive. Option: C. No need to repeat chest X-ray if no TB changes are found, can initiate ATT as the AFB test is positive. Option: D. The patient here tested positive in the sputum smear examination. So ATT should be initiated as soon as possible.

questions.text: Earlier, the anti-tubercular regimens were of a minimum of 18 months. Then the government introduced short course chemotherapy. All of the following are advantages of short-course chemotherapy, except.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Low cost Is incorrect because the introduction of short-course chemotherapy needs high cost, hampering wider use in developing countries.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. As the treatment regimen is of short term, patients will be more compliant Option: B. Treating with 4 drugs initially kill off as many bacilli as possible. This causes rapid bacteriological conversion and decreased the spread to others. It also decreases the risk of relapse. Option: D. short course therapy reduces the failure rates and also a reduction in frequency of emergence of drug resistant bacilli.

questions.text: A presumptive TB patient is sent for spot and early morning sputum smear examination and chest x ray. The first smear turns out to be negative but the chest x ray showed the features of TB. All of the following are done next except.

options.label: A
options.text: Label as negative as sputum smear is 100% sensitive for TB

options.label: B
options.text: Do sputum smear AFB test on second sample

questions.correct_answer: A. Label as negative as sputum smear is 100% sensitive for TB
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Label as negative as sputum smear is 100% sensitive for TB Is right because sputum smear is neither 100% sensitive nor 100% specific. If sputum smear negative cannot be directly labelled as no TB.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. As the first sample report is negative, second sample preferably early morning sample test should be done. Test is done on early morning sample because the bacilli are more concentrated in sputum overnight. Any one sample result if positive, then TB is confirmed. Option: C. The CBNAAT should also be done on second sample along with smear examination. Option: D. Rifampicin sensitivity should be detected by CBNAAT before start of ATT.

questions.text: You are working as medical officer in district hospital in TB OPD. You are explaining the about the fixed drug combinations of anti tubercular drugs to the DOTS providers in a seminar arranged by the department. What are the advantages of FDCs you are included in your presentation except?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Use of monotherapy Is not correct because when the drugs are manufactured as fixed dose combination, drugs cannot be used as monotherapy and it is important in TB management as monotherapy increases the incidence of drug resistance.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. As there will be fewer tablets to swallow, patients acceptance increases and prevents ‘concealed’ irregularality. Option: B. As there will be Fewer tablets to handle, quicker supervision of DOTS increases health worker compliance as well. Option: C. use of 3 or 4 drugs combination lower the emergence of resistance.

questions.text: A patient presented with fever more during end of the day, malaise, productive cough and weight loss. Pulmonary tuberculosis is suspected and sent for sputum smear and chest x ray and sensitivity testing. The results came as drug sensitive tuberculosis. According to which of the following programme, you have to notify this disease?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Nikshay Nikshay is correct. Nikshay is a TB surveillance using case based web based IT system. Central TB division in collaboration with National Information Center has developed application named Nikshay for notification of all TB cases.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Nischay is the programme supplying pregnancy testing kits free of cost to Sub center and ASHA workers Option: C. 99 DOTS is a programme for monitoring treatment intake. In this person should give missed call to the hidden number after taking tablet. Option: D. Nikshay Poshan Abhiyan is for nutritional support to TB patient. Rupees 500/- per month is given to every TB patient during treatment period.

questions.text: Identify the programme with which the given image is associated:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

NTEP Central TB Division (CTD) in collaboration with National Informatics Centre (NIC) has develop a Case Based Web Based application named Nikshay and is represented by the logo above. The word is combination of two Hindi words NI and KSHAY, meaning eradication of TB. RNTCP has been renamed as NTEP now.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. NLEP stands for National Leprosy Elimination Programme and aims to achieve control of leprosy through early detection of cases and DDS (dapsone) monotherapy on an ambulatory basis. Option: C. NPCDCS stands for National Programme for Prevention and Control of Cancer, Diabetes, Cardiovascular diseases and Stroke. Option: D. NVBDCP stands for National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme.

questions.text: A 3 years old child is brought to hospital with fever, cough persisted for 20 days. The child’s mother is recently diagnosed with tuberculosis and is on treatment. What is the next step you do for this child?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Do CBNAAT The child in this case is exposed to tuberculosis and also have complaints suggestive of tuberculosis like prolonged fever and cough. CBNAAT is the investigation of choice.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. Sputum smear microscopy is done if CBNAAT facilities are not readily available or testing is not possible even by referral. Option: C. Chest x ray and tuberculin skin tests are done if MTB is not detected or sputum is not available. But it is not the next step in given case scenario. Option: D. Course of antibiotics is only considered if the sputum smear and CBNAAT does not detect bacilli and chest x ray normal and tuberculin skin test is negative. It is not the next step here.

questions.text: Rajeev is on shorter MDR TB regimen started 2 weeks back. He is very concerned about his health after the diagnosis of MDR TB. He asks you when should chest X-ray be done. When will you do schedule the chest X-ray in follow up?

options.label: B
options.text: At the end of intensive phase, end of treatment, also as and when clinically indicated.

options.label: C
options.text: At the end of 6 months, end of treatment and as and when clinically indicated.

options.label: D
options.text: No need of chest x ray in follow up.

questions.correct_answer: B. At the end of intensive phase, end of treatment, also as and when clinically indicated.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

At the end of intensive phase, end of treatment, also as and when clinically indicated. Chest x ray in shorter MDR regimen should be done at the end of intensive phase, end of treatment and as and when clinically indicated.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. If the patient is on H mono/poly resistant TB regimen, then chest X-ray should be done only as and when clinically indicated. Option: C. Chest x ray at the end of 6 months, end of treatment and as and when clinically indicated is done in all oral longer regimen for MDR/RR TB Option: D. Chest x ray should be done in follow up in all resistant TB cases.

questions.text: Children are affected by tuberculosis usually by the exposure to family members with sputum smear positive tuberculosis. So it is necessary to give TB prophylaxis in them. Which of the following is not correct regarding TB preventive therapy?

options.label: A
options.text: INH 10mg/kg is given daily for 6 months

options.label: B
options.text: It should be given in all symptomatic contacts of active disease.

options.label: C
options.text: It should be given to tuberculin skin test positive children who are receiving immunosuppressive therapy

options.label: D
options.text: It should be given to children who are HIV positive children with tuberculin skin test positive.

questions.correct_answer: B. It should be given in all symptomatic contacts of active disease.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

It should be given in all symptomatic contacts of active disease. TB preventive therapy should be given in asymptomatic contacts, not the symptomatic contacts. If symptoms are present, the patient should be tested for TB and treatment regimen should be started.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. The dose of INH is 10mg/kg daily for 6 months Option: C. All tuberculin skin test positive children who are receiving immunosuppressive therapy like children with nephrotic syndrome, acute leukemia should get chemoprophylaxis for TB. Option: D. Chemoprophylaxis is also recommended for all HIV infected children who are either had a known exposure to an infectious TB case or are tuberculin skin test positive (>/= 5mm) but have no active TB disease.

questions.text: A 24 year old male with a contact history of TB was subjected to CBNAAT. CBNAAT offers Universal Drug Susceptibility Testing (DST) for which of the following drugs?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Rifampacin The Xpert MTB/RIF assay or Cartridge Based Nucleic Acid Amplification Test (CBNAAT) is a semi-automated, molecular assay, which permits rapid TB diagnosis through detection of the DNA of Mycobacterium tuberculosis along with rifampicin resistance status.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Culture can be performed using solid media or automated liquid broth culture systems. Culture-based DST allows for comparison of growth on a drug-containing medium with a control medium to establish the presence of drug resistance. Option: C. Culture can be performed using solid media or automated liquid broth culture systems. Culture-based DST allows for comparison of growth on a drug-containing medium with a control medium to establish the presence of drug resistance. Option: D – Culture can be performed using solid media or automated liquid broth culture systems. Culture-based DST allows for comparison of growth on a drug-containing medium with a control medium to establish the presence of drug resistance.

questions.text: A 36 yr old male was diagnosed with MBR-TB and was sent to the District – DR-TB centre for treatment. Which one of the following is the newer drug recommended for treatment in the management of MDR-TB?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Bedaquiline Bedaquiline is the newer drug included in the Group-A drugs based on WHO MBR-TB treatment guidelines 2020. Bedaquiline demonstrated excellent minimum inhibitory concentrations (MICs) against both drug-sensitive and MDR-TB.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Cycloserine, a cyclic analog to D-alanine, could target alanine racemase and D-alanine ligase, thus blocking the formation of the bacterial cell wall. Cycloserine has been used in TB therapy since the late 1950s and is a Group B drug in WHO MBR-TB treatment guidelines 2020. Option: C. Ethambutol is an antimycobacterial agent that is most commonly used in combination with other drugs in the treatment of tuberculosis. Ethambutol is a Group C drug in WHO MBR-TB treatment guidelines 2020 Option: D – Fluoroquinolones (levofloxacin or moxifloxacin) are core drugs, having bactericidal and sterilising activity included in the Group-A drugs in WHO MBR-TB treatment guidelines 2020.

questions.text: A 38 year old woman gives birth to a baby boy after 38 weeks of gestation. The facilities the new born is getting is part of which programme?

Solution:

FBNC New born care facilities at various levels of public health services that includes newborn care corners (NBCCs) at all points of child birth for primary care ,New born stabilization units (NBSU) at CHC/FRUs for management of selected conditions and Sick Newborn Care Unit (SNCUs) at district/sub district hospitals to care for sick new borns all come under Facility based New born care (FBNC) programme of 2011 as an intervention under National Health Mission (NHM).

questions.text: A medical officer of PHC goes to school where he carries out screening of anemia in adolescents girls. Under programme does this action is part of?

options.label: A
options.text: National iron plus initiative for anemia

questions.correct_answer: A. National iron plus initiative for anemia
questions.explanation:
Solution:

National iron plus initiative for anemia National iron plus initiative for anemia control - • Anemia is a serious public health challenge in India with more than 50% pre among the vulnerable groups such as pregnant women, infants, young child adolescents. Iron deficiency being the most common form nutritional national iron+ initiative was launched by the adolescent division of the mir health and family welfare (MoHFW), government of India. Its aim is to reach the following age groups for supplementation of iron & fc • Age groups covered under this programme are: 6-60 months 5-10 years 10-19 years Pregnant and lactating mothers Under RMNCH+ programme, Has launched the weekly iron and folic acid supplementation (WIFS) progra meet the challenge of high prevalence and incidence of anaemia a adolescent girls and boys. The long term goal is to break the intergenerational cycle of anaemia, th term benefit is of a nutritionally improved human capital. The programme, implemented across the country. Both in rural and urban areas, The key interventions under this programme are as follows: Administration of supervised weekly iron-folic acid Supplements of 100 mg elemental iron and 500 µg folic acid using a fi approach. Screening of target groups for moderate/severe anaemia And referring these cases to an appropriate health facility. biannual de-worming (albendazole 400 mg), six months Apart, for control of helminths infestation. 7. Information and counselling for improving dietary intake and for takin for prevention of intestinal worm infestation.
